articles.author: This Week in AI Engineering
articles.description:
Hello AI Enthusiasts!
Welcome to the Twenty-Second edition of "This Week in AI Engineering"!
This week, Fathom R1 14B cracks one of the world‚Äôs toughest exams while outperforming OpenAI‚Äôs o3-mini, Google open-sources their entire DeepSearch stack, NVIDIA releases Nemotron Research Reasoning Qwen 1.5B, Microsoft introduces Sora-style text-to-video generation in Bing, OpenAI debuts Audio Endeavor and Audio Voyager, and the Agents SDK in TypeScript drops with real-time streaming capabilities.
With this, we'll also explore some under-the-radar tools that can supercharge your development workflow.
Indian AI Model DESTROYS OpenAI o3-mini


Built under India‚Äôs National AI Mission, Fathom R1 14B is a 14 billion-parameter reasoning model developed by Fractal AI. Despite its relatively modest parame‚Ä¶
articles.title: Indian AI model DESTROYS o3-mini, Google DeepSearch is open source, OpenAI's new models and TypeScript SDK, and more

articles.author: Sarvesh
articles.description:
Memory leaks in Node.js applications are stealthy and dangerous. They rarely trigger immediate crashes but slowly degrade performance until your app buckles under pressure. In this post, we'll explore effective techniques and tools to identify and fix memory leaks, using heapdump, clinic.js, and v8-tools.
Whether you're a junior dev trying to understand memory usage or a senior engineer optimizing production APIs, this guide balances foundational concepts with hands-on debugging steps.
Before diving into debugging tools, it's essential to understand how memory leaks occur in Node.js applications. Common causes include:
Unclosed event listeners that accumulate over time
Global variables holding references to large objects
Circular references preventing garbage collection
Closures retaining ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Debugging Memory Leaks in Node.js: A Complete Guide to heapdump, clinic.js, and v8-tools

articles.author: idavidov13
articles.description:
Ever asked an AI for something simple and gotten a bland, generic, or just plain useless answer? üò§
You ask it to "write a blog post about agile," and it gives you a Wikipedia summary. You ask it to "explain a technical concept," and you get a dry, rambling textbook definition. It‚Äôs a common experience ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è, and it stems from a fundamental misunderstanding.
We often treat these powerful tools like casual chat partners. The secret to unlocking high-quality, relevant results is to change your mindset. üîë You‚Äôre not chatting with an AI; you're hiring it for a specific job. And every good hire needs a great job description. ü§ù
The biggest mistake most of us make‚Äîfrom beginners to seasoned developers‚Äîis jumping straight into the task with a vague question. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
This is what leads to generic a‚Ä¶
articles.title: üí°You're Not Chatting With AI, You're Giving It a Job. Here's How

articles.author: William Oliver
articles.description:
Digital transformation has evolved from a buzzword to a business imperative. As we navigate through 2025, organizations worldwide are investing heavily in digital technologies to stay competitive, improve efficiency, and drive innovation. This comprehensive guide explores the latest trends, strategies, and best practices for successful digital transformation in 2025.

The digital transformation journey has reached a critical inflection point in 2025. Direct investment in digital transformation is projected to soar to an impressive USD 8.5 trillion by 2025, representing a robust CAGR of 19% from 2020 to 2025. This massive investment reflects the growing recognition that digital transformation is no longer optional but essential for business survival and growth.
In 2025, digital transformati‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Definitive Guide to Digital Transformation in 2025

articles.author: Shrijith Venkatramana
articles.description:
Hi there! I'm Shrijith Venkatrama, founder of Hexmos. Right now, I‚Äôm building LiveAPI, a first of its kind tool for helping you automatically index API endpoints across all your repositories. LiveAPI helps you discover, understand and use APIs in large tech infrastructures with ease.
Database migrations are a critical part of building and maintaining Go applications. They keep your database schema in sync with your codebase, handle updates, and ensure your app stays reliable as it evolves. Choosing the right migration tool can save you time, reduce errors, and make deployments smoother. In this post, we‚Äôll dive into the best database migration tools for Go, with examples, comparisons, and practical insights to help you pick the right one for your project.
I‚Äôve been through the grind of man‚Ä¶
articles.title: Best Database Migration Tools for Golang

OOPs concepts (Inheritance, Polymorphism, Abstraction, Encapsulation)

Exception Handling
Multithreading (basic understanding)
Java 8 features: Streams, Lambdas, Functional interfaces, Optional
String, StringBuilder, StringBuffer

**  Spring Core:** Dependency Injection, Bean Life Cycle
**Spring Boot:**

Annotations (@RestController, @Autowired, @Service, etc.)
REST API creation
Application properties/yml
CRUD operations with database
Spring Data JPA:
@Entity, @id, @GeneratedValue
JpaRepository, Query methods
Hibernate Basics (Optional if using JPA)

SQL (Important)
 Basic queries: SELECT, JOIN, GROUP BY, ORDER BY, etc‚Ä¶

Have you ever wanted to take your note-taking experience to the next level? üåå What if I told you we could create a beautiful, interactive note-taking application that feels like you're writing in the cosmos? The project structure is as clean as a starry n‚Ä¶

articles.author: Jostin Soza
articles.description:
Hello, everybody! I‚Äôm Jostin, Software Developer and Systems Engineering student. This blog is where I‚Äôll document all my journey into Java development. I‚Äôll talk about Java concepts, share my experiences, and give some tips along the way. I hope this blog helps others who are also learning Java. Feel free to follow along and share thoughts!
Java is one of the most popular programming languages in the world. It‚Äôs widely used in enterprise environments. Learning Java can be very useful if you‚Äôre aiming to get a job at a big company. And of course, it is the best programming language in the world. If you disagree, I don‚Äôt care ‚Äî it‚Äôs a fact. üëæ
Let‚Äôs be honest. Java documentation is not the best. Trying to find something there can be hard, especially when you‚Äôre just starting your Java journey. If you‚Äôre not familiar with the world of programming, I recommend taking a course to get started with programming logic. One great option is ‚ÄúIntroduction to Programming and Computer Science‚ÄîFull Course‚Äù by freeCodeCamp.org.
Link of the video üß†
After that, you should follow the Java Developer Roadmap. Link to the page below üëá
Java Roadmap
I've already started that roadmap, but I actually know more Java than it covers at this point.
In the next posts, I‚Äôll explore all the concepts from that roadmap. If that sounds interesting, feel free to follow along on my profile. Good luck with your learning journey! ‚òï
articles.title: My Java Journey ‚òï

articles.author: Chimobi Roland
articles.description:
Before we dive in, a quick disclaimer ‚Äî I‚Äôm not a professional DevOps engineer, just a developer who needed to fix a slow server. After spending hours tweaking, I want to share my experience so you don‚Äôt waste hours on something that should take five minutes.
Now, here‚Äôs my setup: I‚Äôm running a Django app on a CentOS 9 EC2 Server. For my web server, I chose Nginx for three key reasons: performance, load balancing, and ease of configuration, along with my familiarity with it. I also used Gunicorn as the proxy server to manage the Django services.

The problem:
While testing, I noticed something odd ‚Äî a 3x speed difference between running the Django development server with Nginx routing traffic to it versus running it through Gunicorn.
My first thought was that the application might be too h‚Ä¶
articles.title: I Fixed My Slow Nginx + Gunicorn Setup‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäHere‚Äôs How It Became 3X Faster

articles.author: LNATION
articles.description:
In the last post we learnt how to create a reference to a scalar, an array, and a hash. In this post, we will learn how to dereference these references and some of the caveats that perl has when it comes to dealing with references.
Firstly in Perl it's important to understand that references are scalar values. This means that you can create a reference to a reference, and a reference to a reference to a reference, and so on. This is called a "deep reference" in programming.
To declare a reference to any scalar, you use the backslash operator ('\'). For example:
my $scalar = 42;
my $scalar_ref = \$scalar;

To dereference a scalar reference, you use the dereferencing operator ('$'). For example:
my $value = $$scalar_ref;  # This will give you the value 42

To change the value of the scalar t‚Ä¶
articles.title: Learning Perl - References
